name: Vessel
description: Living liquid machines have overrun a world of unstoppable progress and their inventor must stop the chaos in this game about a man with the power to bring ordinary matter to life!
minimum_requirements: OS: Windows 7 / Vista / XP  Processor: Dual Core 2.0GHz or equivalent processor  Memory: 2GB System RAM  Hard Disk Space: 1.5GB  Video Card: ATi Radeon HD 2400 or NVIDIA GeForce 7600 or better (Shader Model 3.0 needs to be supported)  DirectX®: 9.0c  Sound: DirectX compatible

reviews.review_text: Publisher:   Strange Loop Games  [www.strangeloopgames.com]   Developer:   Indie Pub  [en.wikipedia.org]   Platform:  PC  Controls:  Full Controller Support  Vessel is a fluid based puzzle-platformer in which you play as M. Arkwright, an inventor who created an automaton called a Fluro. They were created to help out with laborious tasks which they can perform better than humans. Only problem is they start evolving and running amok so you need to go through the world of Vessel to fix what they have broken.   To help you out in the game you get a liquid gun with a tank attached to it. You can either spray liquid or suck it into it. It’s also upgradeable with different nozzle tips and larger tanks. With this and the Fluros you will be able to complete the puzzles throughout the world.  You’ll play through three different areas where you will need to repair machinery that the Fluros have broken. The levels consist of a factory, orchard, and mines. Through these levels you will discover new types of Fluro that you can use. You also need to capture each type which will then give you a seed. The seeds can be thrown on the grown and spray with liquid to form whichever Fluro it is. These vary from ones that like to press switches, chase you, collect liquid till they pop, hide from light, or go to the light.   The puzzles in the game are challenging and fun to do. I had a few that really made me think but the fun was in discovering how to get the different Fluros to work for you. The story also wasn’t too bad and did add a little to the game but it was really all about the puzzles. Overall Vessel is a fun challenging puzzle game to play and should not be missed.   Bear Pros:  Great liquid physics Fun challenging puzzles Fluro characteristics     Bear Cons:  Somewhat lackluster ending Only three areas to explore Needs more of these great puzzles (not really a con)
One of my top 3 indie games of all time. Simply brilliant

This is a 2D puzzle platformer with a Victorian era Steampunk setting. You have discovered how to animate water and an industrial revolution occurred because of it. But now your animated “Fluros” are acting a bit off and you've got to fix them.   While I didn't find the puzzles to be very difficult, I Still enjoyed the game. There is a kind of laid back feel to the game and completing the puzzles still gave a feeling of accomplishment. I've come to expect excellent music from indie games and the soundtrack is pretty good here. Wish a soundtrack came with the Bundle. While the controls are clunky; It only affected a small part of the game. The main character kind of reminded me of a puppet on strings, For some reason.   Nothing too taxing, but a pretty decent game.

Controller support: Great! Physics: Wonderful!  Gameplay: Couldn't really get into it. Lots of puzzles that put you through all the motions of moving fluros around even though you know what you want to do.
Solve tricky puzzles with the help of strange water creatures. Very interesting graphics zoomig and harder levels.

Vessel is an excellent 2-D platform puzzle game. There are a few spots that require quick fingers and fast reflexes, although there are many puzzles where you just need to do the right things in the right order. Most of the puzzles are challenging without being impossible, so it is very satisfying when you solve a puzzle.  I rate this game an 8 instead of a 9 because I ran into some game bugs on the final level (accelerator) that made the level unsolvable. I closed the game and restarted, and then I was able to complete the puzzle first try. I think there a few bugs like this in the game where you need to restart the game to make it work right. Still an excellent game and well worth your money.

This game is great. The story, artistic direction, puzzles, gameplay, audio, etc. are all excellent. It's very different from other modern games, but it does not suffer as a result. It was definitely worth the purchase.
The water physics made my computer sad :(

Very interesting game, good weekend choice material. The puzzles are moderate, with a few exception here and there. I'm not really into puzzle games, but Vessel does the genre right. The use of physics with liquids to solve was cool, and the Fluros are fun to use. I like the slight upgrade system that was intergrated as I'm an RPGer, so I love to level up and upgrade equipment. The only bad part was it's over too quickly, I would have love to upgrade and buy more weapons and play more stages. All in all, a great indie IP.
I was charmed by this puzzle-platformer, even though I stopped playing once it started to get complicated.

This game is fun, cute to look at and occasionally difficult. It is nicely put together with good graphics. Some of the puzzles are a little tricky but not too hard. Some of them are large and complex. All are based on fluid dynamics. 7/10

This game. Is amazing and beautiful. The music is really inspirational. Its hard to put it to words. Its piano music with glitchy sounds mixed in.  And gameplay. Is amazing. This game is physics based. Water is the most important thing in the game (like in real life)  I give this game a 9/10 (Take it with a grain of salt. its an indie game)  Graphics: 7 Graphics could vary a bit more  Gameplay: 10 Really innovative. Controls are good  Sound: 9 The soundtrack is amazing.  This is one of my favorite games.

I only played the first 25 mins of this game but man it really has some issues.  I'm using a pretty awesome laptop but I had frame rate issues. The water physics used in this game uses up a ton of performance. Platforming with such choppy frame rate is pretty irritating.  The puzzles use these water clones a lot and getting them to not kill themselves is just frustrating.  I love sidescrolling platform puzzles and I loooovvvve water physics but this game doesn't nail any of this.  Graphics are also not all that impressive.  Adunno, I'm not feeling it in this game.

this is an ok game. It keeps introducing new mechanics and elements throughout the game, but somehow still managed to be somewhat monotonous.   Game is easy until the last section, which is oddly hard. It's difficult to controll the green liquid and get the fluros to go where you want them to in this section. it feels like you lose the control you've been perfecting throughout the rest of the game.   It has a lot of slowdown. My computer isn't the best but it has run more complicated games than this just fine. It just has a lot happening with the liquid dynamics, and background and foreground all moving around. It made the game unplayable at points. I had to keep it at a really low res to play.   To summarize: Just another platform puzzler. Somewhat more unique than most. Not a very interesting story or character, though. A lot of 'upgrades' that don't really do much and feel like fluff. Lots of slowdown on ok computers. somewhat frusting at times because you don't directly control the solutions. Not worth 15$.
Games doesn't feel fluid, physics isn't enjoyable and pace is slow and boring.
Revolutionary and funny mechanics! Can't remember the lore of the game, so pretty standard in that aspect, I guess.  Buy it.
You love water physics? So you like Vessel.
Relaxing, Great Puzzles, Great PhysX fluid fun that never gets old, and beautiful 2D/3D mix. One of a kind game.
The puzzles are excellent, and I completed all the worlds, but I consciously couldn't be bothered to do the final accelerator puzzle. Oh well. Great puzzles all the way until that one though.
Suprisingly deep and brilliant game. My young son and I had a blast playing through it. I'm posting this review primarily for experience points.
Good game, great fluid mecanics, tough puzzels, but ending a bit dissapionting.

I received this game as part of a bundle, but never heard of it before. I Couldn't stop playing it until I finished the story. Now a few years later, and I still never heard anyone mention it, this game is definitely a hidden gem worth checking out.

The game is quite fun, however the controler mechanics are a tad bit buggy. I spent about five minutes trying to jump from one platform to another because the character kept turning mid flight without me wanting them to.  Some of the puzzles are oddly difficult due to it not being quickly aparent what you're supposed to be doing, but all in all, the atmosphere and the actual game play is quite fun.
A nice fun fluid dynamics and reactions platform puzzler. Not a very difficult game at all, either in puzzling or platforming, and thus a good casual between more serious games diversion.
This is a very good game! I love it! I play it every day since i get it
im generally harder to pull to the side scroller puzzle games, but i enjoyed this game and liked your abilities and its use of fluid mechanics etc.
Fun game. Original mechanic.   Most memorable moment: needed to cross some lava, but all my water creatures it turned to steam. Completely stuck for a while. Then, eureka!
I'm enjoying it, Can be very frustrating if you don't enjoy dying in fire/larva don't buy.

The key features on the Vessel store page pretty much sum it up: Realstic simulation of liquid, unique puzzles, 2D/3D hybrid art style and a reasonably well put together suite of game music.  What it doesn't tell you is: 1. The jump mechanic could use some work 2. The equipment upgrades lack detailed descriptions 3. Like all puzzle games there will be times you will be left wondering what needs to be done to solve the puzzle. The last problem stems from the fact that you need to pay close attention to all the visual cues. When you fail to notice key information required to solve the puzzle, the situation is not handled well. A hint system would be beneficial to the game. Recommended for puzzle lovers! <3

Do you want to make beings out of liquids that can do your bidding, then using them solve puzzles? If that sounds cool, then you should go play the demo, which is a good representation of the game as a whole, with the only real difference being there's much more of it. The puzzles range from easy to mind-boggling, though the game is weakest and can get frustrating when it requires precision since the physics aren't precise, though those points are mainly if you want achievements.   Overall, a fun and pretty looking puzzle-platformer that took me about 13 hours to do everything.
Quiet possibly the greatest platform puzzler I've played in recent times. I love it!
Neat puzzler that plays around with liquid physics.

Truly wonderful puzzle game. The beauty of this game comes from the fact that you're solving the puzzles indirectly -- by guiding the gorgeous 'Flurries' (as I call them) around the levels, you make them solve the puzzles for you. Very innovative, requires quite different style of thinking.
It's clever and fun.
The puzzles are excellent, and I completed all the worlds, but I consciously couldn't be bothered to do the final accelerator puzzle. Oh well. Great puzzles all the way until that one though.
This is actually a damn fun game. Unique and clever puzzles and gameplay, a cool ragdoll/physics/flud dynamics engine, and an overall interesting storyline.

This is an interesting puzzle game featuring the creation and use of a variety of creatures made of a variety of substances. On the downside, Vessel's graphics engine seems to have some optimization issues.
This is one of my favorite puzzle games ever. The puzzes are challenging and the story is intriguing, but most of all the Fluros feel alive and give a mysterius atmosphere to it all.
'I Thought This Game Was Cool Before It Won An Award', said everyone that played this in perpetuity.
